title: What part of speech is the word “since”? - Quora

response.answer_text: Adverb, Conjunction, or Preposition Once you know exactly which parts of speech, it will be clear which of the above, that applies.

SINCE is a preposition as well as a subordinating conjunction. As a preposition, it denotes a point of time. It is used only in the present perfect and present perfect continuous tense. E.g. He has been ill since Monday. He has been reading since 4 o' clock. When used as a subordinator, the subordinate clause must be in the simple past. E.g. We have never met since we left the college. (Time clause) I resigned since I had to look after my parents. (Reason clause)
